com.itko.lisa.test

Class TestNode

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.itko.util.test.TestNode
      • com.itko.lisa.test.TestNode
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    com.itko.lisa.model.IWriteXML, NamedType, com.itko.lisa.test.NameGenerator, CloneImplemented, java.lang.Cloneable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    Abend, NormalEnd

    public abstract class TestNode
extends com.itko.util.test.TestNode
implements com.itko.lisa.model.IWriteXML, NamedType, CloneImplemented, com.itko.lisa.test.NameGenerator
    TestNode is the heart of LISA. It is the class that implements the base functionality of every test node, and is the polymorphic mechanism by which all custom test nodes are connected to the LISA framework. Every existing and custom test node extends TestNode.

    Every activity with the system under test or that starts or stops a test is a TestNode; more broadly, every state in the test execution workflow is a TestNode.

    For example, ending a test ocurrs by the execution of a TestNode like the NormalEnd TestNode. Abnormal ends are processed by the Abend TestNode.

    CRITICAL NOTE: TestNodes cannot store session-scoped state in them! For efficiency, they are not cloned as they are used, so all concurrently running test instances share the same TestNode class instance. Be sure you always use the TestExec's state management for what you would typically do as object attribute data. In fact, there is no other place than the TestExec to store state.

    The baseline activities for TestNode, primarily performed before the custom TestNode extention is invoked are to:

    • process any DataSets that are referenced
    • regenerate any RandomSets that are referenced
    • Invoke filters, unless they have been turned off
    • process any properties defined as part of this node in the test case
    • ensure there is a next node to execute if one was not set by the custom TestNode extension's logic

    There are 2 extensibility points for TestNodes, the initialize() and execute() methods. See their Javahelp for more.

    See Also:
    initialize(com.itko.lisa.test.TestCase,org.w3c.dom.Element), execute(com.itko.lisa.test.TestExec)

      • raiseNodeFailedEvent

        public static void raiseNodeFailedEvent(TestExec ts,
                        java.lang.String nextNode,
                        java.lang.String shortDesc,
                        java.lang.String longDesc,
                        java.lang.Throwable throwable)
        This method is to be used by all steps to raise nodeFailed events. The reason is so we can determine if it is a continue or continue (Quite Mode). We raise this event for all next steps except "continue quite" to enable negative testing scenarios. This method will also set the nextNode for you so it completes several tasks in one call.
        Parameters:
        ts - - The current TestExec
        nextNode - - The next node to fire. usually from the onExNext() method.
        shortDesc - - The short dec in LISA events
        longDesc - - The longer Description in LISA events
        throwable - - Can be null if you do not have an exception/Throwable to pass here.

      • raiseNodeFailedEvent

        public static void raiseNodeFailedEvent(TestExec ts,
                        java.lang.String nextNode,
                        java.lang.String shortDesc,
                        java.lang.String longDesc,
                        java.lang.Throwable throwable,
                        boolean parseProps)
        This method is to be used by all steps to raise nodeFailed events. The reason is so we can determine if it is a continue or continue (Quite Mode). We raise this event for all next steps except "continue quite" to enable negative testing scenarios. This method will also set the nextNode for you so it completes several tasks in one call.
        Parameters:
        ts - - The current TestExec
        nextNode - - The next node to fire. usually from the onExNext() method.
        shortDesc - - The short dec in LISA events
        longDesc - - The longer Description in LISA events
        throwable - - Can be null if you do not have an exception/Throwable to pass here.
        parseProps - - Do we parse props? The default is true.

      • setThink

        public void setThink(java.lang.String t)
        This method takes a string in the form "from-to" or just "thislong", and will parse it to set the TestNode's think from and think to attributes appropriately. If there's a parsing error, think from and to are 0. No Exception is thrown
        Parameters:
        t - - the string to parse

      • setRemoteServer

        public void setRemoteServer(java.lang.String server)
        Used to tell the test case execution framework to remotely stage and execute this particular node. Setting this to an empty string, null ,or SimulatorInfo.LOCAL_SIM means local execution. Otherwise, we will attempt to execute on the given SimulatorServer
        Parameters:
        server - is the RMI server name of the SimulatorServer that should run this guy
        See Also:
        SimulatorServer

      • getRemoteServer

        Returns:
        null if we are staging this node locally or the RMI name of the remote server
        See Also:
        SimulatorServer

      • getFilters

        public java.util.Vector<FilterInterface> getFilters()
        Every TestNode has a collection of Filters that are defined only to be executed for that Node. This is where most Filters will be defined since they typically execute on a specific result of a Node, rather than in the TestCase's global Filters collection. This method will give you the collection of Filters for this TestNode. It does not include the global Filters. The elements in this Vector are the actual objects that implement the FilterInface.
        Returns:
        collection of Filters defined for this Node.
        See Also:
        FilterInterface

      • getFiltersAsList

        public java.util.List<FilterInterface> getFiltersAsList()
        Similar to getFilters but returns an unmodifiable copy of the getFilters() vector in a typesafe and unsynchronized List. Much better for concurrent iteration under load...
        Returns:

      • getRandLists

        public java.util.Vector<java.lang.String> getRandLists()
        Random Lists are only defined at the global level. However, every Node that should regenerate a random value from a Random List must be set to do so explicitly. So every Node maintains a collection of Random Lists that it is set to regenerate upon execution. The elements of this collection are the string names of the Random Lists, not the actual reference to the RandSet object. That can be fetched with the name given here.
        Returns:
        the collection of Random Lists that are regenerated by this Node
        See Also:
        RandSet

      • getDataSets

        public java.util.Vector<java.lang.String> getDataSets()
        Data Sets are only defined at the global level, i.e., as children of the Test Case, not a particular Node. However, every Node that wants to read another record from a Data Set must do so explicitly. So every Node maintains a collection of Data Sets that it is set to invoke a new record from upon execution. The elements of this collection are the string names of the Data Sets, not the actual reference to the DataSet object. That can be fetched with the name given here.
        Returns:
        the collection of Data Sets for this Node
        See Also:
        DataSet

      • getDocumentation

        public java.lang.String getDocumentation()
        Simple text field for providing extended documentation of the node.
        Returns:
        the documentation field for this node.

      • setDocumentation

        public void setDocumentation(java.lang.String doc)
        Simple text field for providing extended documentation of the node.

      • initialize

        public abstract void initialize(TestCase test,
              org.w3c.dom.Element e)
                         throws TestDefException
        This method is called during the construction of a TestNode. Once the TestNode base class tags have all been processed, the entire XML Element fragment and the TestCase object we are building this node within are passed to this method for custom XML tag processing. For example, the com.itko.lisa.URLTrans extends TestNode and has a custom <url> tag. Delay most of the hard core initialization until the prepare() method that you are also able to override. The reason is that TestCase objects (and these TestNodes within) are constructed anywhere on the network that users stage tests FROM, but the test may float all over the network before it is actually run. For example, our built-in web services node needs to generate code, build a jar, and drop that jar on the Classpath. It's pointless to do that from the client machine that is asking a server to the run the test. Instead, it must be done in every simulator process that is going to run the test. So prepare is useful for that.
        Throws:
        TestDefException
        See Also:
        prepare(TestCase)

      • writeSubXML

        public void writeSubXML(java.io.PrintWriter pw)
        Most models will want to override this method so that you can provide programmatic model creation support. That is if someone wanted to construct a test case or VS model or whatever from scratch and then call writeXML() to serialize their creation for later reconstruction. Most of LISA's built-in nodes support this. The only ones that don't are not practically feasible to author from code. But if that's what you need, use a ScriptNode and quote the code right? What actually happens here is that the model calls writeXML() on this Node, and the node then calls this method to emit the custom attributes into the stream.
        Parameters:
        pw - the stream we are writing to
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the node does not support serialization to XML

      • execute

        protected abstract void execute(TestExec ts)
                         throws TestRunException
        This is the method called by TestNode when all pre-processing related to node execution is complete and LISA is prepared for the custom node logic to be performed. For example, DataSets have been read, Filters pre methods executed, and etc. During custom node logic execution, you can set the next node to be executed by calling TestExec.setNextNode(). If you don't, then the CheckResults will be queried, and eventually this node's Next Node attribute will be used. Typical responsibilities of a node are to do the following:
        • Raise a TestEvent.EVENT_EXECTIME event of your actual processing time on the system under test. The short should be this node node, and the long should be the time in millis. You do this with a call to TestExec.raiseEvent()
        • Use TestEvent.EVENT_NODEMSG, TestEvent.LOG_MSG, and other events as appropriate
        • Call TestExec.setLastResponse( Object o ) to inform the framework of the response you received from the system under test.

        State Management

        State is a big thing -- that's the dynamic data part of the test. You get access to all of LISA's properties in this test via calls in TestExec, like TestExec.getStateValue(). You can also save state as a side affect of execution with TestExec.setStateValue(). When you need your TestNode to convert strings with {{ notation into their current value, use TestExec.parseInState(). Are you seeing how important TestExec is?
        Throws:
        TestRunException - -Only use the TestRunException as a way to report testcase or LISA type errors, NOT errors in the system under test. For that report the errors into the log and set the next node as a the Abend node. The reason is that TestRunExceptions will halt the test and stop everything in its tracks. So if you are that off in the weeds, great. If not, then resist the urge.
        See Also:
        TestExec, TestExec.raiseEvent(int, String, String), TestExec.setLastResponse(Object)

      • prepare

        public void prepare(TestCase test)
             throws LisaException
        This method gives the test node the ability to do one-time initialization of its logic just before the TestExec(s) are created and the testing commences. Realize that initialize() is invoked from within the client JVM. This method is called in the JVM that is really going to execute the test.
        Throws:
        TestRunException
        LisaException

      • destroy

        public void destroy(TestExec ts)
        This method gives the test node the ability to do final cleanup of resources when the test has ended and will no longer be calling the node.
        Parameters:
        ts - the TestExec that we're ending (why we're being destroyed)

      • executeNode

        public void executeNode(TestExec ts)
                 throws TestRunException
        public void executeNode( TestExec ts ) Method that is called internally by LISA to execute a node. This method does the prep work and then down-calls into the custom TestNode.execute() After calling into the subclass, it then performs post execution work, then if needed, figures out what the next Node in the workflow should be, and sets that in the TestExec.
        Parameters:
        ts - - the test execution environment object for this test
        Throws:
        TestRunException

      • determineThinkTimeDelay

        public long determineThinkTimeDelay(TestExec ts,
                           java.lang.String thinkSpec)
        This method provides the means for determining how much to actually delay by converting the given think time spec into a think time, adjusting it by the staging doc's think time percentage and the starting time of the current step.
        Parameters:
        ts - the current test exec.
        thinkSpec - the think time spec to use.
        Returns:
        the amount of time to delay.
